docs.title: AI-Assisted Architecture
docs.text: Welcome to AI-Assisted Architecture — an opinionated methodology for leveraging AI agents in enterprise and solution architecture practice.

docs.title: What is AI-Assisted Architecture?
docs.text:
AI-Assisted Architecture is a framework that enables architects to:

  • Accelerate research through AI-powered synthesis of technology landscapes
  • Draft documentation with AI assistance while maintaining human accountability
  • Apply patterns consistently using AI agent recommendations
  • Track provenance of AI-generated content for governance and audit
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    AI-Assisted Architecture Operating Model                      │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

   ┌──────────────────────┐     ┌──────────────────────┐     ┌────────────────┐
   │   HUMAN ARCHITECTS   │     │     AI AGENTS        │     │   GOVERNANCE   │
   │  (EA, SA, Platform)  │     │  (Research, Draft)   │     │   (Controls)   │
   └──────────┬───────────┘     └──────────┬───────────┘     └───────┬────────┘
              │                            │                         │
              ▼                            ▼                         ▼
   ┌──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
   │                        ARCHITECTURE WORKFLOWS                             │
   │                                                                           │
   │  ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌────────────┐ │
   │  │  Research   │ → │  Analysis   │ → │   Design    │ → │  Review    │ │
   │  │  (AI-led)   │    │  (AI+Human) │    │ (AI draft)  │    │ (Human)    │ │
   │  └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └────────────┘ │
   └──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/dermotcanniffe/ai-assisted-architecture.git

# Start using the methodology
# 1. Review the methodology phases

docs.title: For Organizations
docs.text:
Organizations can adopt this framework through a fork-and-customize model:

  1. Fork the core repository
  2. Customize templates, branding, and governance
  3. Extend with organization-specific building blocks
  4. Sync updates from upstream
  5. Contribute improvements back to the community

Organization Adoption Guide :material-arrow-right:

docs.text: Background, vision, and strategic context for the project.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: AI-Assisted Architecture is an open-source methodology for leveraging AI agents in enterprise and solution architecture practice. This section provides insight into the thinking behind the project.

docs.title: Project Origins
docs.text:
AI-Assisted Architecture emerged from practical experience applying AI tools to architecture work. Key observations:

  1. AI tools are powerful but need governance
  2. Architects are stretched and need productivity help
  3. Existing methodologies don't address AI assistance
  4. Organizations need guidance on adopting AI in architecture

This project aims to fill that gap with a practical, governed, open-source approach.

docs.title: Author
docs.text:
Dermot Canniffe

Enterprise and Solution Architect with experience in: - Financial services architecture - AI/ML platform architecture - Enterprise architecture frameworks - Architecture governance

docs.title: Design Decisions
docs.text:
Key design decisions made in creating AI-Assisted Architecture.

Author: Dermot Canniffe Date: February 2026

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Need a structure that supports: - Documentation site generation - Multi-organization adoption - Core vs customization separation

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Three-tier structure: 1. core/ - Versioned methodology and agents 2. extensions/ - Extension points and examples 3. docs/ - Documentation site source

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Clear separation of concerns
  • Organizations can override without touching core
  • Documentation site builds cleanly

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Architecture patterns need to be: - Reusable across platforms - Vendor-specific when needed - Stable yet evolvable

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Two-tier building blocks: - ABB (Architecture Building Block): Logical, vendor-agnostic - SBB (Solution Building Block): Physical, vendor-specific

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• ABBs provide stable reference points
  • SBBs capture technology evolution
  • Clear mapping between capability and implementation
  • Enables multi-cloud strategies

docs.title: Context
docs.text: AI-generated content needs: - Clear origin identification - Review state tracking - Audit trail

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Three-state model: - ai-raw - AI-generated, not reviewed - ai-curated - Reviewed by generalist - draft - Validated by SME

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Aligns with EU AI Act requirements
  • Matches C2PA and NIST standards
  • Simple enough to adopt
  • Clear quality gates

docs.title: Context
docs.text: AI agents need: - Clear purpose - Reproducible behavior - Integration with multiple tools

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Single-responsibility agents with: - Explicit instructions (steps) - Defined inputs/outputs - Artifact-oriented design - Tool-agnostic instructions

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Easier to test and validate
  • Works across Cursor, Claude Code, Copilot
  • Composable for complex workflows

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Organizations need to: - Adopt the methodology - Customize for their needs - Stay current with updates - Contribute back improvements

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Fork-and-customize model: - Core as git subtree/submodule - overrides/ for customizations - Semantic versioning for updates - PR-based contribution

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Organizations control their pace
  • Updates don't break customizations
  • Clear contribution path
  • Community can grow

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Need static site generation that: - Works with Markdown - Supports navigation - Deploys to GitHub Pages - Is easy to maintain

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: MkDocs Material as primary, with Docusaurus config available.

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• MkDocs is simpler (Python vs Node.js)
  • Material theme is excellent
  • Wide adoption in technical docs
  • Easy migration path if needed

docs.title: Context
docs.text: AI tools are evolving rapidly: - GitHub Copilot established - Cursor gaining adoption - Claude Code emerging - More tools coming

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Support multiple tools with: - Tool-specific guides - Common agent instructions - No hard dependency on any tool

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Users choose their tools
  • Methodology survives tool changes
  • Broader adoption potential

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Architecture work needs tracking: - Scope definition - Task breakdown - Progress monitoring - Deliverable tracking

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: File-based work management: - scope.md - Scope definition - plan.md - Activities and tasks - progress.yaml - Machine-readable status - Agent-driven updates

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Version controlled with architecture
  • AI agents can read/update
  • No external tool dependency
  • Simple and portable

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Architecture documents often have ASCII diagrams: - Quick to create in text - Version control friendly - But look unprofessional in published docs

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: ASCII-to-image conversion agents: - Detect ASCII in markdown - Convert to Draw.io format - Replace with image references - Maintain both formats

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Authors can work in ASCII
  • Published docs look professional
  • Source remains version-controllable
  • Automated conversion reduces friction

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Need licenses that: - Encourage adoption - Allow commercial use - Require attribution - Protect scripts separately

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Dual licensing: - CC BY 4.0 for documentation/methodology - MIT for code/scripts

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• CC BY 4.0 is standard for documentation
  • Attribution requirement builds community
  • MIT for code is permissive and familiar
  • Commercial use encouraged

docs.title: Context
docs.text: Organizations using AI for architecture need: - Security team buy-in - Clear boundaries - Governance controls - Regulatory alignment

docs.title: Decision
docs.text: Structured security dialogue framework with: - Pre-conditions checklist - Information flow controls - Candidate decisions - Regulatory mapping

docs.title: Rationale
docs.text:
• Proactive engagement better than reactive
  • Clear controls reduce friction
  • Regulatory alignment future-proofs
  • Reusable across organizations

docs.title: Organization Adoption Model
docs.text:
How organizations adopt, customize, and contribute to AI-Assisted Architecture.

Author: Dermot Canniffe Date: February 2026

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
AI-Assisted Architecture is designed for multi-organization adoption with:

  • Core stability - Versioned, tested methodology
  • Customization - Override without breaking updates
  • Currency - Easy sync with upstream
  • Contribution - Path to improve the core

docs.title: Core Repository Structure
docs.text:
ai-assisted-architecture/
├── core/                          # VERSIONED CORE
│   ├── VERSION                    # Semantic version
│   ├── methodology/               # Methodology content
│   ├── agents/                    # Agent definitions
│   ├── governance/                # Governance frameworks
│   ├── templates/_base/           # Base templates
│   └── building-blocks/           # Reference BBs
│
├── extensions/                    # EXTENSION POINTS
│   ├── templates/                 # Template customization
│   ├── themes/                    # Branding customization
│   └── building-blocks/           # BB extension guide
│
└── docs/                          # DOCUMENTATION

docs.title: Organization Fork Structure
docs.text:
org-ai-assisted-architecture/
├── core/                          # GIT SUBTREE from upstream
│   └── (versioned core content)
│
├── overrides/                     # ORG CUSTOMIZATIONS
│   ├── templates/                 # Custom templates
│   ├── branding/                  # Logo, colors, headers
│   ├── governance/                # Org policies
│   └── agents/                    # Org agent customizations
│
├── org-content/                   # ORG-SPECIFIC CONTENT
│   ├── building-blocks/           # Internal ABBs/SBBs
│   ├── patterns/                  # Org patterns
│   └── standards/                 # Org standards
│
├── work/                          # ACTIVE WORK (not shared)
│
└── ORG-CONFIG.yaml               # Org configuration

docs.title: Organization Configuration
docs.text:
# ORG-CONFIG.yaml
organization:
  name: "Your Organization"
  short_name: "yourorg"

upstream:
  repository: "https://github.com/dermotcanniffe/ai-assisted-architecture"
  version_pinned: "1.0.0"
  auto_sync: false

overrides:
  templates:
    - path: "templates/abb-template.md"
      reason: "Added org metadata fields"
  governance:
    - path: "governance/data-classification.md"
      reason: "Org-specific classification"

contributions:
  pending:
    - pr: "#45"
      description: "Improved template"
  accepted:
    - pr: "#32"
      description: "Bug fix"

docs.title: Semantic Versioning
docs.text:
MAJOR.MINOR.PATCH

MAJOR  → Breaking changes (templates, schemas)
         Organizations: Manual review required

MINOR  → New features, templates, agents
         Organizations: Review recommended

PATCH  → Bug fixes, clarifications
         Organizations: Safe to auto-sync

docs.title: Version Compatibility
docs.text: Core Org Pinned Action 2.1.3 2.1.0 Auto-sync (patch) 2.2.0 2.1.0 Review (minor) 3.0.0 2.1.0 Migration (major)

docs.title: Template Overrides
docs.text:
Organizations can extend base templates:

# overrides.yaml
overrides:
  templates:
    abb-template:
      base: "core/templates/_base/abb-template.md"
      override: "overrides/templates/abb-template.md"
      merge_strategy: "extend"  # Add to base

Extend adds org fields to base template:

---
# Standard fields (from core)
id: ABB-XXX
name: ""

# Org-specific fields (added)
org_metadata:
  cost_center: ""
  compliance_tags: []
---

docs.title: Branding Overrides
docs.text:
Organizations customize look and feel:

overrides/branding/
├── theme.yaml        # Colors, fonts
├── logo.svg          # Org logo
├── logo-dark.svg     # Dark mode logo
└── header-footer.md  # Standard content

docs.title: Agent Customizations
docs.text:
Organizations extend agent instructions:

overrides:
  agents:
    work-management:
      base: "core/agents/work-management/AGENTS.md"
      override: "overrides/agents/work-management/AGENTS.md"
      merge_strategy: "append"  # Add org instructions

docs.title: Pull Updates
docs.text:
# Fetch upstream changes
git fetch upstream

# Review changes
git log HEAD..upstream/main --oneline

# Merge (or rebase)
git merge upstream/main

# Resolve conflicts (org overrides take precedence)

docs.title: Sync Configuration
docs.text:
# upstream.yaml
sync:
  strategy: "git-subtree"

merge:
  auto_merge_paths:
    - "core/methodology/**"
    - "core/tooling/**"

  manual_review_paths:
    - "core/templates/**"
    - "core/agents/**"

  never_merge_paths:
    - "core/templates/_base/abb-template.md"  # Fully overridden

docs.title: Process
docs.text:
1. Develop improvement in org fork
         │
         ▼
2. Generalize (remove org-specific)
         │
         ▼
3. Submit PR to upstream
         │
         ▼
4. Review by maintainer
         │
         ▼
5. Merge → Available to all orgs

docs.title: Contribution Types
docs.text: Type Description Template Improved base templates Building Block New reference ABBs/SBBs Agent Enhanced agent instructions Documentation Methodology improvements Bug Fix Corrections and clarifications

docs.title: PR Requirements
docs.text:
• Organization-agnostic content
  • Follows style guide
  • Includes documentation
  • Tested in org context

docs.title: Do
docs.text:
• ✅ Keep core/ unmodified
  • ✅ Use overrides/ for customizations
  • ✅ Document override rationale
  • ✅ Pin versions for stability
  • ✅ Review before syncing
  • ✅ Contribute generic improvements

docs.title: Don't
docs.text:
• ❌ Modify core files directly
  • ❌ Include org info in contributions
  • ❌ Auto-sync without review
  • ❌ Forget provenance updates
  • ❌ Create divergent forks

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Phase Action Outcome Fork Create org repository Own instance Configure Set ORG-CONFIG.yaml Define org settings Customize Populate overrides/ Org branding, templates Extend Add org-content/ Org-specific content Sync Pull upstream updates Stay current Contribute Submit PRs Improve core

This model enables organizations to: - Adopt quickly - Customize freely - Update safely - Contribute back

docs.title: Vision for AI-Assisted Architecture
docs.text: Author: Dermot Canniffe Date: February 2026 Status: Living Document

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
AI-Assisted Architecture is an open-source methodology that enables enterprise and solution architects to leverage AI agents as productivity multipliers while maintaining governance, quality, and human accountability.

This document captures the vision, design decisions, and strategic considerations that shaped this project.

docs.title: Current State Challenges
docs.text:
Architects face increasing pressure to deliver more, faster:

Challenge Impact Volume of work More initiatives, same-sized teams Technology complexity Rapidly evolving landscape Documentation burden Quality expectations increasing Research demands Staying current requires constant effort Consistency Maintaining standards across artifacts

docs.title: The AI Opportunity
docs.text:
AI tools (GitHub Copilot, Cursor, Claude Code) offer significant acceleration potential:

  • Research synthesis - AI can gather and summarize information rapidly
  • Draft generation - Initial content created in minutes, not hours
  • Pattern application - Consistent application of standards
  • Analysis acceleration - Preliminary analysis as starting point

docs.title: The Governance Gap
docs.text:
However, using AI in architecture work raises concerns:

  • Quality uncertainty - AI outputs may contain errors
  • Provenance opacity - Unclear what's AI-generated vs human-created
  • Accountability questions - Who owns AI-assisted decisions?
  • Security considerations - What information can flow to AI?

docs.title: Key Principles
docs.text: Principle Description Augmentation, not automation AI assists, humans decide Transparency Clear provenance for all AI-assisted content Governance-first Controls built into the methodology Platform-agnostic Works with multiple AI tools and cloud platforms Community-driven Open-source, contributions welcome

docs.title: 1. Opinionated Methodology
docs.text:
An end-to-end process from enterprise context to solution design:

Enterprise Context → Capabilities → ABBs → SBBs → Solution Design

Why opinionated? Without a clear methodology, AI assistance becomes ad-hoc and inconsistent. An opinionated approach enables: - Consistent artifacts - Reusable prompts - Quality predictability - Training and onboarding

docs.title: 2. Building Block Framework
docs.text:
Separating logical (ABB) from physical (SBB) architecture:

Aspect ABB SBB Nature Logical Physical Vendor Agnostic Specific Stability Stable Evolves Example "API Gateway" "AWS API Gateway v2"

Why this matters: ABBs provide stable anchors for architecture while SBBs capture the evolving technology landscape.

docs.title: 3. AI Agent System
docs.text:
Purpose-built agents for architecture work:

Agent Category Agents Purpose Work Management Start, Progress, Status, Pivot Manage architecture work items ASCII Image Detect, Convert, Replace Convert ASCII diagrams to images Architecture Research, Gap Analysis, Pattern Selection Assist with architecture tasks

docs.title: 4. Governance Framework
docs.text:
Controls for AI-assisted architecture:

  • Provenance Standard: Three-state model (ai-raw → ai-curated → draft)
  • Security Dialogue Framework: Structured engagement with security teams
  • Human Review Gates: Quality gates before publication
  • Data Classification: Rules for information flow to AI

docs.title: 5. Multi-Organization Adoption Model
docs.text:
Enable organizations to adopt, customize, and contribute:

CORE REPOSITORY (versioned, stable)
        │
        ├── Organization A (fork + customize)
        ├── Organization B (fork + customize)
        └── Organization C (fork + customize)
                │
                └── Contributions back to core

docs.title: Why MkDocs over Docusaurus?
docs.text:
Factor MkDocs Material Docusaurus Setup Simple (Python) More complex (Node.js) Focus Documentation Docs + blog + custom Community Technical docs standard Broader web focus

Decision: MkDocs Material for simplicity and documentation focus. Can migrate later if needed.

docs.title: Why Multiple AI Tool Support?
docs.text:
Different tools have different strengths:

Tool Strength GitHub Copilot Enterprise adoption, wide IDE support Cursor Deep codebase understanding, agent mode Claude Code Advanced reasoning, large context

Decision: Support all three with tool-specific guides. Don't lock users into one tool.

docs.title: Why Semantic Versioning?
docs.text:
Organizations need stability while the core evolves:

  • PATCH: Safe to auto-sync
  • MINOR: Review recommended
  • MAJOR: Breaking changes, manual migration

Decision: Strict semver with clear upgrade paths.

docs.title: Why Agent-Optimized Building Blocks?
docs.text:
Building blocks include agent_hints:

agent_hints:
  selection_criteria: |
    Use this ABB when...
  composition_notes: |
    Typically paired with...
  common_mistakes: |
    Do not use for...

Decision: Metadata designed for AI comprehension accelerates agent-assisted architecture.

docs.text: Aspect Approach License CC BY 4.0 (docs), MIT (code) Governance Benevolent dictator (initial), community later Contributions Welcome, with quality bar Commercialization None planned; focus on adoption

docs.title: Agents
docs.text: AI agents that automate and assist with architecture work.

docs.title: Work Management Agents
docs.text:
Manage architecture work items through their lifecycle:

Agent Purpose Location Start Work Initialize work items with plan.md, progress.yaml .ai-assisted-work/agents/work-management/ Progress Work Execute tasks, update deliverables .ai-assisted-work/agents/work-management/ Work Status Report progress, identify blockers .ai-assisted-work/agents/work-management/ Pivot Work Rescope and replan when needed .ai-assisted-work/agents/work-management/

Work management agents are provided via the .ai-assisted-work submodule. See core/agents/work-management for local copies.

docs.title: ASCII Image Agents
docs.text:
Convert ASCII diagrams to proper images:

Agent Purpose Detect ASCII Find ASCII diagrams in markdown Convert ASCII Generate Draw.io XML from ASCII Replace ASCII Update documents with image references Validate Check diagram consistency

ASCII image agents are provided via the .ai-assisted-work submodule.

docs.title: Architecture Assistants
docs.text:
Assist with architecture tasks:

Agent Purpose Status Research Technology research and synthesis Planned Gap Analysis Capability gap identification Planned Pattern Selector Recommend appropriate patterns Planned ABB Composer Select and compose building blocks Planned

Architecture assistant agents are planned for future releases.

docs.title: With Cursor
docs.text:
Agents are available as Cursor rules:

.cursor/rules/
├── work-management.mdc
├── ascii-image.mdc
├── start-work.mdc
├── progress-work.mdc
└── ...

Invoke with commands like /start-work or /progress-work.

docs.title: With Claude Code
docs.text:
Reference agent instructions in your prompts:

claude "Follow the start-work agent instructions to initialize 
a new work item for [description]"

docs.title: With GitHub Copilot
docs.text:
Use @workspace with agent instruction files:

@workspace #file:agents/work-management/start-work.md 
Initialize a work item for [description]

docs.title: Agent Design Principles
docs.text: How agents are designed for AI-Assisted Architecture.

docs.title: 1. Single Responsibility
docs.text:
Each agent has one clear purpose:

✅ Good: "Start Work Agent" - initializes work items
❌ Bad: "Work Agent" - does everything with work

docs.title: 2. Explicit Instructions
docs.text:
Agents provide clear, step-by-step instructions:

## Steps

1. Read the scope description
2. Create plan.md with activities and tasks
3. Create progress.yaml with initial state
4. Report what was created

docs.title: 3. Artifact-Oriented
docs.text:
Agents produce specific artifacts:

Agent Input Output Start Work Scope description plan.md, progress.yaml Convert ASCII Markdown with ASCII .drawio, .png files Research Research question Research summary

docs.title: 4. Composable
docs.text:
Agents can be chained:

Start Work → Progress Work → Work Status → Complete Work

docs.title: 5. Idempotent Where Possible
docs.text:
Running an agent twice should be safe:

✅ "Update progress.yaml with current status" - safe to repeat
❌ "Add a new activity" - would duplicate

docs.title: Standard Agent File
docs.text:
# Agent Name

Brief description of what this agent does.

## Purpose

Detailed explanation of the agent's purpose.

## Prerequisites

What must be true before using this agent:

- Prerequisite 1
- Prerequisite 2

## Inputs

| Input | Required | Description |
|-------|----------|-------------|
| input_1 | Yes | Description |
| input_2 | No | Description |

## Steps

1. First step
2. Second step
3. Third step

## Outputs

| Output | Description |
|--------|-------------|
| output_1 | What this produces |

## Examples

### Example 1: [Scenario]

[Example usage and output]

## Error Handling

| Error | Resolution |
|-------|------------|
| error_1 | How to handle |

docs.title: Cursor Rule Format
docs.text:
---
name: agent-name
description: Brief description
type: manual
---

# Agent Name

[Agent content following standard structure]

docs.title: Agent Hints for Building Blocks
docs.text:
Building blocks include hints for agents:

agent_hints:
  selection_criteria: |
    Use this ABB when the solution requires [criteria]
  composition_notes: |
    Typically paired with ABB-YYY for [scenario]
  common_mistakes: |
    Do not use for [anti-pattern]

These hints help agents: - Select appropriate building blocks - Compose them correctly - Avoid common errors

docs.title: Manual Testing
docs.text:
1. Run the agent with sample input
  2. Verify outputs match expectations
  3. Test edge cases

docs.title: Validation Checklist
docs.text:
• Agent produces expected artifacts
  • Artifacts are well-formed
  • Provenance is set correctly
  • Error cases handled gracefully

docs.title: Creating New Agents
docs.text:
1. Identify the need - What task needs automation?
  2. Define scope - Single responsibility
  3. Design artifacts - What does it produce?
  4. Write instructions - Clear, step-by-step
  5. Add examples - Show expected behavior
  6. Test thoroughly - Verify with real scenarios
  7. Document - Add to agent index

docs.title: Building Blocks
docs.text: Reusable architecture and solution building blocks.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Building blocks are the fundamental components of solutions:

┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                           Building Block Hierarchy                               │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

   Capabilities              ABBs                    SBBs
       │                       │                       │
       │                       │                       │
   ┌───┴───┐              ┌────┴────┐            ┌────┴────┐
   │ What  │              │  How    │            │  With   │
   │ the   │  ──────────► │  (Logic)│ ─────────► │  What   │
   │business│              │         │            │(Vendor) │
   │ needs │              │         │            │         │
   └───────┘              └─────────┘            └─────────┘

   "Customer    →   "API Gateway"   →   "AWS API Gateway"
    Channel"                             "Azure API Mgmt"
                                         "Kong on K8s"

docs.title: ABB vs SBB
docs.text: Aspect ABB SBB Nature Logical, conceptual Physical, concrete Vendor Agnostic Specific Stability Stable over time Evolves with technology Purpose Define what's needed Define how to build

docs.title: ABB Library (Planned)
docs.text:
Reference Architecture Building Blocks will include:

  • API Gateway
  • Event Broker
  • Identity Provider
  • Vector Database
  • And more...

docs.title: SBB Library (Planned)
docs.text:
Solution Building Blocks by platform:

  • AWS implementations
  • Azure implementations
  • GCP implementations

Note: Reference building blocks are planned for future releases. Organizations can create their own using the templates in core/templates/_base/.

docs.title: Agent Integration
docs.text:
Building blocks include metadata for AI agents:

agent_hints:
  selection_criteria: |
    Use this ABB when...
  composition_notes: |
    Typically paired with...
  common_mistakes: |
    Do not use for...

See the ABB and SBB templates in core/templates/_base/ for the full schema.

docs.title: Your First Project
docs.text: Create your first AI-assisted architecture project step by step.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
In this guide, you'll:

  1. Set up a project structure
  2. Define enterprise context
  3. Model capabilities
  4. Create building blocks
  5. Design a solution

docs.title: Step 1: Create Project Structure
docs.text:
mkdir my-first-project
cd my-first-project

# Create directory structure
mkdir -p {capabilities,building-blocks/{abbs,sbbs},solutions,decisions,work}

# Initialize git
git init

Create a README:

# My First Project

AI-assisted architecture project using the AIAA methodology.

## Structure

- `capabilities/` - Business capability model
- `building-blocks/` - ABBs and SBBs
- `solutions/` - Solution designs
- `decisions/` - Architecture Decision Records
- `work/` - Active work items

docs.title: Step 2: Define Enterprise Context
docs.text:
Create capabilities/enterprise-context.md:

---
provenance:
  origin: collaborative
  review_state: ai-raw
---

# Enterprise Context

## Vision
[Describe the target state]

## Business Drivers
1. [Driver 1]
2. [Driver 2]

## Constraints
- Regulatory: [constraints]
- Technical: [constraints]
- Organizational: [constraints]

## Stakeholders
| Stakeholder | Interest | Influence |
|-------------|----------|-----------|
| [Name] | [Interest] | High/Medium/Low |

AI Prompt: 

Help me define the enterprise context for a [domain] project.
Consider business drivers, constraints, and key stakeholders.

docs.title: Step 3: Model Capabilities
docs.text:
Create capabilities/capability-model.md:

---
provenance:
  origin: ai-generated
  review_state: ai-raw
---

# Capability Model

## L0: [Domain]

### L1: [Capability Area 1]
- L2: [Specific Capability 1.1]
- L2: [Specific Capability 1.2]

### L1: [Capability Area 2]
- L2: [Specific Capability 2.1]

AI Prompt: 

Based on the enterprise context, create a capability hierarchy for [domain].
Use L0 → L1 → L2 structure with clear descriptions.

docs.title: Step 4: Create an ABB
docs.text:
Create building-blocks/abbs/abb-example.md:

---
id: ABB-001
name: "[Building Block Name]"
version: "1.0.0"
provenance:
  origin: ai-generated
  review_state: ai-raw
---

# ABB-001: [Building Block Name]

## Purpose
[Why this building block exists]

## Capabilities Realized
- [Capability 1]
- [Capability 2]

## Interfaces

### Provided
| Interface | Type | Description |
|-----------|------|-------------|
| [Name] | REST/Event/etc | [Description] |

### Consumed
| Interface | Type | Description |
|-----------|------|-------------|
| [Name] | REST/Event/etc | [Description] |

## Quality Attributes
| Attribute | Requirement |
|-----------|-------------|
| Availability | 99.9% |
| Latency | <100ms p99 |

## SBB Realizations
- [SBB-AWS-001](../sbbs/sbb-aws-001.md) - AWS implementation
- [SBB-AZURE-001](../sbbs/sbb-azure-001.md) - Azure implementation

docs.title: Step 5: Design a Solution
docs.text:
Create solutions/solution-001.md:

---
id: SOL-001
name: "[Solution Name]"
provenance:
  origin: ai-generated
  review_state: ai-raw
---

# Solution Design: [Name]

## Overview
[Brief description of the solution]

## Use Case
[What problem this solves]

## Building Blocks Used
| ABB | SBB | Purpose |
|-----|-----|---------|
| ABB-001 | SBB-AWS-001 | [Purpose] |

## Component Architecture

[Describe components and their relationships]

## Integration Architecture

[Describe how components integrate]

## Deployment Architecture

[Describe deployment topology]

## Decisions
- [ADR-001](../decisions/adr-001.md) - [Decision topic]

docs.title: Step 6: Review and Refine
docs.text:
1. Review AI outputs for accuracy
  2. Update provenance to ai-curated
  3. Get SME validation where needed
  4. Update provenance to draft

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: Complete guide to setting up AI-Assisted Architecture.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: Component Required Purpose Git Yes Version control IDE (VS Code/Cursor/IntelliJ) Yes Development environment AI Tool Yes AI assistance Python 3.9+ Optional Document conversion scripts Node.js 18+ Optional Docusaurus (if using)

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/dermotcanniffe/ai-assisted-architecture.git
cd ai-assisted-architecture

docs.title: Using MkDocs
docs.text:
# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # Linux/Mac
.\venv\Scripts\activate   # Windows

# Install dependencies
pip install -r requirements-docs.txt

# Serve locally
mkdocs serve

# Build static site
mkdocs build

docs.title: VS Code
docs.text:
1. Install recommended extensions:
  2. GitHub Copilot
  3. Markdown All in One
  4. Draw.io Integration

  5. YAML

  6. Configure settings:

{
  "editor.formatOnSave": true,
  "markdown.preview.breaks": true,
  "files.associations": {
    "*.md": "markdown"
  }
}

docs.title: Cursor
docs.text:
1. Download from cursor.sh
  2. Import VS Code settings (optional)
  3. Configure AI preferences in Settings → AI

docs.title: IntelliJ IDEA

  2. GitHub Copilot
  3. Markdown Navigator Enhanced
  4. PlantUML Integration

docs.title: GitHub Copilot
docs.text:
1. Subscribe at github.com/features/copilot
  2. Install extension in your IDE

# Authenticate

docs.title: Organization Adoption Guide
docs.text: How organizations can adopt, customize, and contribute to AI-Assisted Architecture.

docs.title: Step 1: Fork the Repository
docs.text:
# Fork via GitHub UI, then clone your fork
git clone https://github.com/YOUR-ORG/ai-assisted-architecture.git
cd ai-assisted-architecture

# Add upstream remote
git remote add upstream https://github.com/dermotcanniffe/ai-assisted-architecture.git

docs.title: Step 2: Create Organization Structure
docs.text:
# Create override directories
mkdir -p overrides/{templates,branding,governance,agents}
mkdir -p org-content/{building-blocks,patterns,standards}
mkdir -p work

Your structure:

your-org-ai-assisted-architecture/
├── core/                    # From upstream (don't modify)
├── overrides/               # Your customizations
│   ├── templates/           # Custom templates
│   ├── branding/            # Logo, colors, headers
│   ├── governance/          # Org governance docs
│   └── agents/              # Org agent customizations
├── org-content/             # Org-specific content
│   ├── building-blocks/     # Internal ABBs/SBBs
│   ├── patterns/            # Org patterns
│   └── standards/           # Org standards
└── work/                    # Active work (not shared)

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Your Organization
docs.text:
Create ORG-CONFIG.yaml:

organization:
  name: "Your Organization"
  short_name: "yourorg"
  domain: "yourorg.com"

branding:
  primary_color: "#003087"
  secondary_color: "#FF6B35"
  logo: "overrides/branding/logo.svg"

upstream:
  repository: "https://github.com/dermotcanniffe/ai-assisted-architecture"
  branch: "main"
  version_pinned: "1.0.0"    # Pin to specific version
  auto_sync: false           # Manual sync only

overrides:
  templates: []              # List templates you override
  governance: []             # List governance docs you override

contributions:
  pending: []                # PRs to upstream
  accepted: []               # Merged contributions

docs.title: Step 4: Customize Templates
docs.text:
Copy and modify templates:

# Copy base template
cp core/templates/_base/abb-template.md overrides/templates/

# Edit with your customizations
# - Add org-specific metadata fields
# - Include org header/footer
# - Add compliance sections

Example customization:

---
# Standard fields (from core)
id: ABB-XXX
name: ""
version: "1.0.0"

# Org-specific fields (your addition)
org_metadata:
  cost_center: ""
  data_classification: ""
  compliance_tags: []
---

docs.title: Internal Building Blocks
docs.text:
# Create org-specific ABBs
cat > org-content/building-blocks/abb-org-identity.md << 'EOF'
---
id: ABB-ORG-001
name: "Organization Identity Service"
version: "1.0.0"
org_specific: true
---

# ABB-ORG-001: Organization Identity Service

[Your org-specific building block...]
EOF

docs.title: Organization Standards
docs.text:
# Create org standards
cat > org-content/standards/data-classification.md << 'EOF'
# Data Classification Standard

Organization-specific data classification levels...
EOF

docs.title: Step 6: Sync from Upstream
docs.text:
When new versions are released:

# Fetch upstream changes
git fetch upstream

# Review what's changed
git log HEAD..upstream/main --oneline

# Merge (or rebase) carefully
git merge upstream/main

# Resolve any conflicts in overrides
# Your overrides take precedence

docs.title: Version Pinning
docs.text:
For stability, pin to specific versions:

# In ORG-CONFIG.yaml
upstream:
  version_pinned: "1.0.0"

Only sync when ready:

git fetch upstream
git checkout v1.1.0  # Specific version tag

docs.title: Step 7: Contribute Back
docs.text: When you have improvements to share:

docs.title: 1. Generalize Your Contribution
docs.text:
Remove org-specific content:

# Create contribution branch
git checkout -b contrib/improved-abb-template

# Copy your override to a clean version
cp overrides/templates/abb-template.md contrib-abb-template.md

# Remove org-specific fields
# Make it generic and reusable

docs.title: 2. Submit Pull Request
docs.text:
# Push to your fork
git push origin contrib/improved-abb-template

# Create PR to upstream via GitHub UI

docs.title: 3. PR Template
docs.text:
## Summary
[What this contributes]

## Type
- [ ] Template improvement
- [ ] New building block
- [ ] Agent enhancement
- [ ] Documentation

## Organization-Agnostic
- [ ] No company-specific references
- [ ] Reusable across industries
- [ ] Follows contribution guidelines

docs.title: Do
docs.text:
• :white_check_mark: Keep core/ unmodified
  • :white_check_mark: Use overrides/ for customizations
  • :white_check_mark: Document what you override and why
  • :white_check_mark: Pin versions for stability
  • :white_check_mark: Contribute generic improvements back

docs.title: Don't
docs.text:
• :x: Modify files in core/ directly
  • :x: Include org-specific info in contributions
  • :x: Auto-sync without review
  • :x: Forget to update provenance

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
• GitHub Discussions
  • Issue Tracker

docs.text:
Create this structure for your architecture work:

my-architecture/
├── capabilities/           # Business capabilities

│   ├── abbs/              # Architecture Building Blocks

docs.title: Start with Enterprise Context
docs.text:
Ask your AI assistant:

Research the business drivers and constraints for [your domain].
Consider regulatory requirements, technology trends, and organizational goals.

docs.title: Model Capabilities
docs.text:
Based on the enterprise context, identify the L0 and L1 business capabilities
needed for [your domain]. Structure as a hierarchy with descriptions.

docs.title: Identify Building Blocks
docs.text:
For capability [X], what Architecture Building Blocks (ABBs) are needed?
Consider integration, security, and operational requirements.

docs.title: Design Solutions

Include component architecture, integration points, and deployment considerations.

docs.title: Step 4: Track Provenance
docs.text:
Add provenance metadata to AI-assisted documents:

---
provenance:
  origin: ai-generated
  review_state: ai-raw    # or ai-curated, draft
---

Review states:

State Meaning ai-raw AI-generated, not reviewed ai-curated Reviewed for structure by generalist draft Validated by subject matter expert

docs.title: Step 5: Review and Publish
docs.text:
Human Review Required

Never publish AI-generated content without human review.

  1. Generate draft with AI assistance
  2. Review for accuracy and completeness
  3. Update provenance to ai-curated or draft
  4. Proceed through governance workflow

docs.title: Governance
docs.text: Governance frameworks for AI-assisted architecture work.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
AI-assisted architecture requires governance to ensure:

  • Quality - AI outputs meet standards
  • Transparency - AI involvement is visible
  • Accountability - Humans own decisions
  • Compliance - Regulatory requirements met

docs.title: Security Dialogue Framework
docs.text:
Framework for engaging with security teams on AI usage:

  • Pre-conditions for AI-assisted architecture
  • Information flow controls
  • Output governance
  • Candidate decisions for approval

docs.title: Provenance Standard
docs.text:
Three-state model for tracking AI content:

State Meaning ai-raw AI-generated, not reviewed ai-curated Reviewed by generalist draft Validated by SME

docs.title: Data Classification
docs.text:
Rules for what data can flow to AI tools:

Classification External AI Enterprise AI Public ✅ ✅ Internal ⚠️ Sanitized ✅ Confidential ❌ ⚠️ Limited Restricted ❌ ❌

docs.title: Human Review Gates
docs.text:
Quality gates requiring human review:

Gate Minimum State Internal reference ai-curated Stakeholder review draft Governance forum draft External publication draft

docs.title: Governance Flow
docs.text:
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                         Governance Flow for AI Content                           │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

   AI Generates          Generalist Reviews       SME Validates
        │                       │                       │
        ▼                       ▼                       ▼
   ┌─────────┐             ┌─────────┐             ┌─────────┐
   │ ai-raw  │ ──────────► │ai-curated│ ──────────► │  draft  │
   └─────────┘             └─────────┘             └─────────┘
        │                       │                       │
   No human review         Structure OK           Content accurate
   May have errors         Links valid            Ready for review
   Working only            Internal use           Can publish

docs.title: Regulatory Alignment
docs.text:
This framework aligns with:

Regulation Alignment EU AI Act Article 50 Provenance labeling NIST AI 100-4 Content transparency C2PA 2.0 Provenance tracking

docs.text:

  2. Follow review gates before sharing

  4. Document decisions with ADRs

  2. Implement provenance tracking
  3. Define data classification rules
  4. Establish review workflows

docs.title: Data Classification
docs.text: Rules for what data can flow to AI tools in AI-assisted architecture work.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Data classification determines what information can be shared with AI assistants based on sensitivity and risk.

docs.title: Classification Levels
docs.text: Level Description External AI Enterprise AI Public Publicly available information Yes Yes Internal Internal business information Sanitized only Yes Confidential Sensitive business information No Limited Restricted Highly sensitive (PII, secrets) No No

docs.title: Safe for AI Assistance
docs.text:
• Public documentation
  • Open source code
  • Published standards and frameworks
  • Generic patterns and templates
  • Hypothetical scenarios

docs.title: Requires Sanitization
docs.text:
• Internal architecture documents (remove specific names)
  • Design patterns (anonymize client references)
  • Technical specifications (remove proprietary details)

docs.title: Never Share with AI
docs.text:
• Customer PII
  • Credentials and secrets
  • Security vulnerabilities
  • Unreleased product details
  • Legal or regulatory privileged information

docs.title: Implementation
docs.text:
When using AI assistance:

  1. Review content before sharing - Check for sensitive data
  2. Sanitize where needed - Replace specifics with generic terms
  3. Use placeholders - {CLIENT}, {SYSTEM}, {ENDPOINT}
  4. Document what was shared - For audit purposes

docs.title: Related
docs.text:

  • Provenance Standard

docs.title: Human Review Gates
docs.text: Quality gates requiring human review before AI-assisted content can progress.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Human review gates ensure AI-assisted architecture outputs meet quality standards before wider distribution.

docs.title: Review Gate Levels
docs.text: Gate Required State Reviewer Purpose Working Draft ai-raw Self Personal use only Internal Reference ai-curated Peer Team sharing Stakeholder Review draft Senior architect External presentation Governance Forum draft Architecture board Formal approval External Publication draft + sign-off Lead architect Public release

docs.title: ai-raw → ai-curated
docs.text:
Generalist review checks:

  • Structure is logical
  • No obvious errors
  • Links work
  • Formatting correct
  • Provenance declared

docs.title: ai-curated → draft
docs.text:
SME review validates:

  • Technical accuracy
  • Completeness
  • Alignment with standards
  • Appropriate recommendations
  • Ready for stakeholders

docs.title: Review Workflow
docs.text:
AI Output  →  Self Review  →  Peer Review  →  SME Review  →  Approval
(ai-raw)      (ai-raw)        (ai-curated)    (draft)        (approved)

docs.title: Documentation
docs.text:
All reviews should be documented:

  • Reviewer name
  • Review date
  • State transition
  • Comments or changes made

docs.title: Related
docs.text:
• Provenance Standard
  • Data Classification

docs.title: Provenance Standard
docs.text: A three-state model for tracking AI-generated content.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
The provenance standard provides visibility into:

  • Origin - How content was created
  • Review State - What validation has occurred
  • Accountability - Who reviewed and when

docs.title: Provenance States
docs.text:
┌──────────┐     Generalist      ┌──────────────┐      SME        ┌─────────┐
│  AI-RAW  │ ──── Review ──────► │  AI-CURATED  │ ── Validation ─►│  DRAFT  │
└──────────┘                     └──────────────┘                 └─────────┘
     │                                  │                              │
No human review              Structural integrity            Technical accuracy
May contain errors           Obvious issues fixed            SME-approved

docs.title: ai-raw
docs.text:
Definition: AI-generated content with no human review.

Characteristics: - Generated by AI agent - May contain errors or hallucinations - Not verified for accuracy - For working drafts only

Usage: Personal working drafts, initial generation

docs.title: ai-curated
docs.text:
Definition: Reviewed by a generalist for structural integrity.

Characteristics: - Structure follows templates - Links and references valid - Obvious errors corrected - Language is clear - Technical accuracy NOT verified

Usage: Internal team reference, peer review

docs.title: draft
docs.text:
Definition: Validated by subject matter expert.

Characteristics: - Technical content verified - Architectural decisions sound - Standards compliance confirmed - Ready for formal review

Usage: Stakeholder review, governance submission, publication

docs.title: YAML Frontmatter
docs.text:
---
title: "Document Title"
version: "1.0.0"

provenance:
  origin: ai-generated          # How created
  review_state: ai-raw          # Current state

  # For ai-curated and draft:
  curated_by: "Name"
  curated_date: "2026-01-31"

  # For draft only:
  validated_by: "SME Name"
  validated_date: "2026-02-01"
  sme_domain: "Security"
---

docs.title: Origin Values
docs.text: Origin Definition ai-generated Primarily created by AI human-authored Primarily created by human collaborative Significant AI and human contribution vendor-provided From external vendor template-derived Generated from templates

docs.title: ai-raw → ai-curated
docs.text:
Reviewer: Any team member

Checklist: - [ ] Structure follows template - [ ] All sections complete - [ ] Links and references valid - [ ] Diagrams readable - [ ] No obvious errors - [ ] Language clear

docs.title: ai-curated → draft
docs.text:
Reviewer: Subject Matter Expert

Checklist: - [ ] Technical content accurate - [ ] Decisions sound - [ ] Standards compliance verified - [ ] Dependencies identified - [ ] Risks assessed

docs.title: Quality Gates
docs.text: Gate Minimum State Working draft ai-raw Team review ai-curated Stakeholder review draft Governance forum draft Wiki publication draft External sharing draft

docs.title: Warning Banner
docs.text:
Documents with ai-raw state should include:

> ⚠️ **AI-Generated Content - Not Reviewed**
> 
> This document was generated by AI and has not been reviewed.
> Content may contain errors. Do not use for decision-making.

docs.title: Regulatory Alignment
docs.text:
This standard aligns with:

  • EU AI Act Article 50: AI content labeling requirements
  • C2PA 2.0: Content provenance tracking
  • NIST AI 100-4: Digital content transparency

docs.title: Quick Reference
docs.text: Scenario Origin Review State AI drafted, no review ai-generated ai-raw AI drafted, structure reviewed ai-generated ai-curated AI drafted, SME validated ai-generated draft Human wrote with AI help collaborative ai-curated Vendor docs imported vendor-provided ai-curated

docs.title: Security Dialogue Framework
docs.text:
A framework for engaging with Security teams on AI-assisted architecture.

Author: Dermot Canniffe Date: February 2026 Status: Reference Framework

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This framework provides a structured approach for architects to engage with Security teams to establish:

  • Pre-conditions for AI-assisted architecture
  • Information flow controls
  • Output governance
  • Candidate decisions requiring approval

docs.title: What AI Does
docs.text: Capability Description Research Synthesis Gather and summarize technical information Draft Generation Create initial document structure and content Pattern Application Apply established patterns to new contexts Analysis Acceleration Preliminary analysis for human review

docs.title: What AI Does NOT Do
docs.text: Exclusion Rationale Make final architecture decisions Human accountability Access production systems Operational risk Process customer PII Data classification Approve governance records Human authority

docs.title: Foundational Controls
docs.text: # Condition Description F1 Approved AI Tool List Security-approved tools for architecture use F2 Data Classification Guidance What classifications can flow to AI F3 Architect Training Mandatory training before access F4 Audit Logging Capability to log AI interactions F5 Data Loss Prevention DLP controls for AI interactions

docs.title: Process Controls
docs.text: # Condition Description P1 Human Review Gate No AI content published without review P2 Provenance Labeling All AI content clearly labeled P3 Version Control AI artifacts tracked in Git P4 Approval Workflow Defined approval for AI artifacts P5 Exception Process Escalation for edge cases

docs.title: Technical Controls
docs.text: # Condition Description T1 Network Controls AI tool access via policy T2 Data Residency Processing meets residency requirements T3 Model Selection Approved models for sensitivity levels T4 Prompt Templates Approved templates for sensitive contexts T5 Output Filtering Safeguards against sensitive data leakage

docs.title: Workspace Information Categories
docs.text: Category Examples Sensitivity A. Public Knowledge Standards, vendor docs Low B. Architecture Patterns Building blocks, patterns Internal C. Solution Design DOAPs, ADRs Internal-Confidential D. Strategic Context Roadmaps, capability gaps Confidential E. Security Details Threat models, controls Confidential-Restricted F. Cost/Commercial Pricing, budgets Confidential G. Customer Reference Journey context Confidential

docs.title: Proposed Flow Rules
docs.text: Category Cloud AI Enterprise AI Controls A. Public ✅ Allowed ✅ Allowed None B. Patterns ⚠️ Decision ✅ Allowed Review for IP C. Designs ⚠️ Decision ✅ Allowed No PII D. Strategy ⚠️ Decision ✅ Allowed Redact sensitive E. Security ❌ Prohibited ⚠️ Limited Strong controls F. Commercial ❌ Prohibited ⚠️ Limited Redact figures G. Customer ❌ Prohibited ⚠️ Limited No PII

docs.title: Output Types
docs.text: Type Description Research Summaries Synthesized information Draft Documents Initial document content Code/Config Technical artifacts Analysis Results Structured analysis Diagrams Visual artifacts

docs.title: Usage Rules
docs.text: Output Direct Use After Review After SME Research ❌ ✅ Internal ✅ Publish Drafts ❌ ⚠️ Working ✅ Publish Code ❌ ⚠️ Non-prod ✅ Prod Analysis ❌ ✅ Working ✅ Decision Diagrams ❌ ✅ Internal ✅ Publish

docs.title: Provenance as Control
docs.text:
Three-state model tracks AI involvement:

┌──────────┐     Generalist      ┌──────────────┐      SME        ┌─────────┐
│  AI-RAW  │ ──── Review ──────► │  AI-CURATED  │ ── Validation ─►│  DRAFT  │
└──────────┘                     └──────────────┘                 └─────────┘

docs.title: Control Functions
docs.text: Function How Provenance Addresses It Transparency Visibility into AI involvement Accountability Documented reviewer at each stage Quality Gate Prevents unreviewed content reaching stakeholders Audit Trail Full traceability via Git + metadata Risk Stratification Different rules per provenance state

docs.title: Decision Summary
docs.text: ID Topic Priority Risk CD-01 Information Flow Policy High Medium CD-02 Output Usage Policy High Low CD-03 Provenance Enforcement High Low CD-04 Approved AI Tools Critical Medium CD-05 Data Classification Mapping Critical High CD-06 Training Requirements Medium Low CD-07 Audit Log Requirements Medium Low CD-08 Exception Process Medium Low CD-09 Web Search Enablement Critical Medium CD-10 Future Tooling (Cursor, Claude) Low N/A

docs.title: Tooling
docs.text:
1. Can existing GitHub Copilot approval extend to architecture work?
  2. Can web search be enabled for research?
  3. Can Python conversion tools run locally?

docs.text:
1. What classifications can flow to AI?
  2. Can workspace files be indexed by AI?
  3. What sanitization is required?

docs.title: Governance
docs.text:
1. What logging requirements apply?
  2. What human review is required?
  3. Is provenance labeling acceptable as a control?
  4. What training should architects complete?

docs.title: Methodology
docs.text: AI-Assisted Architecture follows an opinionated, end-to-end methodology from enterprise context through solution design.

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text:
Our methodology is built on these principles:

Principle Description Capabilities First Always start with business capabilities, not technology Separation of Concerns ABBs (logical) distinct from SBBs (physical) Platform Agnostic Core ABBs work across any cloud or on-premise Traceability Every artifact traces to capabilities Agent-Optimized Metadata designed for AI comprehension Human Accountability AI assists, humans decide

docs.title: Methodology Flow
docs.text:
┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐
│                    AI-Assisted Architecture Methodology                          │
└─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘

  Phase 1              Phase 2              Phase 3              Phase 4
┌─────────────┐     ┌─────────────┐     ┌─────────────┐     ┌─────────────┐
│  ENTERPRISE │     │ CAPABILITY  │     │ ARCHITECTURE│     │  SOLUTION   │
│   CONTEXT   │ ──► │  MODELING   │ ──► │  BUILDING   │ ──► │  BUILDING   │
│             │     │             │     │   BLOCKS    │     │   BLOCKS    │
└─────────────┘     └─────────────┘     └─────────────┘     └─────────────┘
      │                   │                   │                   │
   Vision             L0 → L1 → L2        Logical,            Vendor-
   Drivers            Capability          Platform-           Specific
   Constraints        Hierarchy           Agnostic            Realization
                      Maturity
                                               │                   │
                                               ▼                   ▼
                                         ┌─────────────────────────────┐
                                         │      SOLUTION DESIGN        │
                                         │  • Component Architecture   │
                                         │  • Integration Architecture │
                                         │  • Deployment Architecture  │
                                         └─────────────────────────────┘
                                                       │
                                                       ▼
                                         ┌─────────────────────────────┐
                                         │     DECISIONS (ADRs)        │
                                         └─────────────────────────────┘

docs.title: 1. Enterprise Context
docs.text:
Establish the strategic context for architecture work:

  • Vision and target state
  • Business drivers and goals
  • Constraints (regulatory, technical, organizational)
  • Stakeholder analysis

Detailed phase documentation coming soon.

docs.title: 2. Capability Modeling
docs.text:
Define what the business needs to do:

  • Capability hierarchy (L0 → L1 → L2)
  • Capability assessment and maturity
  • Gap analysis
  • Capability roadmap

Detailed phase documentation coming soon.

docs.title: 3. Architecture Building Blocks
docs.text:
Define logical, platform-agnostic components:

  • ABB identification from capabilities
  • ABB specification
  • Interface definition
  • Quality attributes

See Building Blocks for templates and examples.

docs.title: 4. Solution Building Blocks
docs.text:
Map ABBs to vendor-specific implementations:

  • SBB selection
  • Platform patterns (AWS, Azure, GCP)
  • Technology decisions

See Building Blocks for templates and examples.

docs.title: 5. Solution Design
docs.text:
Compose building blocks into solutions:

  • Solution design canvas
  • Component architecture
  • Integration architecture
  • Deployment architecture

Detailed phase documentation coming soon.

docs.title: 6. Decisions
docs.text:
Document architecture decisions:

  • Decision framework
  • Option analysis
  • Architecture Decision Records (ADRs)

See Templates for ADR template.

docs.title: AI Integration Points
docs.text:
Each phase has specific AI integration:

Phase AI Assists With Enterprise Context Stakeholder analysis, constraint research Capabilities Gap analysis, maturity assessment ABBs Pattern identification, interface design SBBs Technology research, option comparison Solution Design Draft generation, integration patterns Decisions Option analysis, consequence mapping

docs.title: Philosophy
docs.text: The guiding principles behind AI-Assisted Architecture.

docs.title: 1. Capabilities First
docs.text:
Always start with business capabilities, not technology.

Technology choices are implementation details. Capabilities represent what the business needs to do, independent of how it's done.

❌ Wrong: "We need Kubernetes"
✅ Right: "We need Container Orchestration capability"

docs.title: 2. Separation of Concerns
docs.text:
ABBs (logical) are distinct from SBBs (physical).

Aspect ABB SBB Nature Logical, conceptual Physical, concrete Vendor Agnostic Specific Stability Stable Evolves with technology Example "API Gateway" "AWS API Gateway v2"

docs.title: 3. Platform Agnostic Core
docs.text:
ABBs work across any cloud or on-premise.

Your architecture patterns should be portable. Vendor lock-in should be a conscious decision, not an accident.

docs.title: 4. Traceability
docs.text:
Every artifact traces to capabilities.

Capability → ABB → SBB → Solution Component
     ↑                          ↓
     └────── ADR ←──────────────┘

If you can't trace an artifact to a capability, question why it exists.

docs.title: 5. Agent-Optimized
docs.text:
Metadata designed for AI comprehension.

Building blocks include agent_hints that help AI agents: - Select appropriate blocks - Understand composition rules - Avoid common mistakes

docs.title: 6. Human Accountability
docs.text:
AI assists, humans decide.

AI agents accelerate work but never: - Make final architecture decisions - Approve governance records - Bypass human review

docs.title: What AI Does Well
docs.text: Task AI Contribution Research Synthesize information, compare options Drafting Generate initial content quickly Analysis Identify patterns, gaps, inconsistencies Consistency Apply templates and standards uniformly

docs.title: What Humans Must Do
docs.text: Task Human Responsibility Decisions Evaluate trade-offs, commit to direction Validation Verify accuracy, appropriateness Judgment Apply context AI lacks Accountability Own the outcomes

docs.title: Provenance is Non-Negotiable
docs.text:
Every AI-assisted artifact must declare its origin and review state.

provenance:
  origin: ai-generated
  review_state: ai-raw | ai-curated | draft

docs.title: Quality Gates
docs.text: Gate Requirement Internal Reference ai-curated minimum Stakeholder Review draft preferred Formal Governance draft required External Publication draft required

docs.title: For Architects
docs.text:
1. Use AI for first drafts - Let AI generate, you refine
  2. Always validate - AI can hallucinate or be outdated
  3. Maintain traceability - Link everything to capabilities
  4. Document provenance - Track AI involvement

docs.title: For Organizations
docs.text:
1. Establish governance - Define AI usage boundaries
  2. Train architects - Ensure consistent practices
  3. Monitor quality - Review AI-assisted outputs
  4. Evolve practices - Learn and improve continuously

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: AI-Assisted Architecture is about augmentation, not automation. AI agents make architects more productive while humans retain accountability for decisions and outcomes.

docs.title: Glossary
docs.text: Key terms and definitions for AI-Assisted Architecture.

docs.title: ABB (Architecture Building Block)
docs.text: A logical, platform-agnostic component that realizes one or more capabilities. ABBs define what is needed without specifying how it's implemented.

docs.title: ADR (Architecture Decision Record)
docs.text: A document that captures an important architectural decision, including the context, options considered, and rationale for the chosen option.

docs.title: Agent
docs.text: An AI system configured with specific instructions to perform a defined task, such as work management or diagram conversion.

docs.title: AI-Curated
docs.text: A provenance state indicating that AI-generated content has been reviewed by a generalist for structural integrity but not technically validated.

docs.title: AI-Raw
docs.text: A provenance state indicating AI-generated content that has not been reviewed by a human. May contain errors.

docs.title: Capability
docs.text: A business ability that an organization needs, independent of how it's delivered. Organized hierarchically (L0 → L1 → L2).

docs.title: Capability Hierarchy
docs.text: A structured decomposition of business capabilities from high-level (L0) through detailed (L2).

docs.title: Draft
docs.text: A provenance state indicating that content has been validated by a subject matter expert and is ready for formal review.

docs.title: Enterprise Context
docs.text: The strategic setting for architecture work, including vision, business drivers, constraints, and stakeholders.

docs.title: Platform Agnostic
docs.text: Designed to work across multiple technology platforms (AWS, Azure, GCP, on-premise) without modification.

docs.title: Provenance
docs.text: The documented origin and validation history of content, tracking how it was created and what reviews it has undergone.

docs.title: SBB (Solution Building Block)
docs.text: A vendor-specific implementation of an Architecture Building Block. SBBs specify exactly how an ABB is realized on a particular platform.

docs.title: SME (Subject Matter Expert)
docs.text: A domain expert qualified to validate technical accuracy in their area of expertise.

docs.title: Traceability
docs.text: The ability to follow the chain of relationships between architecture artifacts, from capabilities through to solution components.

docs.title: Work Item
docs.text: A unit of architecture work with defined scope, plan, and tracking. Managed through plan.md, progress.yaml, and scope.md files.

docs.title: Workspace Structure
docs.text:
Recommended repository structure:

your-architecture-repo/
├── .ai-assisted-work/    # Submodule with agents
├── .cursor/rules/        # Cursor rule files
├── core/                 # Methodology and templates
├── docs/                 # Documentation
└── change/               # Work items

docs.title: Agent Configuration
docs.text:
AI agents are configured via:

  1. Cursor rules (.cursor/rules/*.mdc) - Always-on guidance
  2. Agent instruction files - Detailed agent behavior
  3. Building block metadata - AI hints for selection

See Agents for details on available agents.
